properties.name: .5 Million Sinkhole :: Richmond, VA
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving2821 e. broad st., richmond, va60+ foot crater opened during Tropical Storm Gaston in August 2004. Work has begun to refill the crater, which swallowed street, sidewalks, and a few cars. Though rumors stirred that the sinkhole was a result of the Church Hill train tunnel collapse, it turns out it the area used to be a ravine (and the storm forced waters to run their natural, long-forgotten course).

properties.name: Abandoned Hydroelectric Plant :: Belle Isle
properties.description: Posted by ShaunirvingCool old power plant that\'s open for you to walk through... just the sort of interesting abandoned industrial site the world needs more of (but lacks thanks to our lawsuit-happy society!). Easiest to get to by hiking across the bridge from Tredegar Iron Works and following the paths.

properties.name: Belle Isle Park
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving    Belle Isle has had a storied past: native American village, Civil War POW camp, horse track, and industrial site. Now, it\'s a public park with many elements from its historic past... making it one of Richmond\'s most intriguing sites. This 54-acre expanse has always been there, but was made more accessible with the construction of a downtown pedestrian bridge about 10 years ago. To get there, you\'ll walk it--suspended above the raging Hollywood Rapids, and dangling from the interstate above. It sounds quite treacherous, but it\'s not. Once you\'re there, follow the path that heads south (parallel to the overpass). You\'ll pass (and be able to wander through) remnants of the park\'s industrial past: stone walls, steel frames, and even an entire hydroelectric plant. The ruins are what make Belle Isle truly unique; in an era of high liability, it\'s one of the few sites where you can legally wander through such abandonment. The trail leads around to the Rapids and past other vestiges of its life as a POW camp. Earthen mounds and defensive positions have worn down over time, but they\'re still there. Do be prepared to walk over some rugged terrain, especially if you opt to climb the hill in the center of the island. Wade out into the water at your own risk, since the Rapids are deceptively strong. And be sure to visit the bathroom before hitting the island, since bathroom facilities aren\'t available. Belle Isle is located across the James River from Tredegar Iron Works. To get there from downtown, go south on 5th Street, and hang a right when the road ends. Free parking is on your right, under the railroad trestle and before the Ethyl Corporation parking lot.

Indoor and outdoor seating, beer on tap. A little on the pricey end for what it is, but worth the money.

properties.name: Craddock-Terry Shoe Factory
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving In 1888, John Craddock, A. P. Craddock, T.M. Terry and Max Guggenheimer formed Craddock-Terry and Company as a wholesale distributing house for "boots, shoes and rubbers." The firm later became The Craddock-Terry Shoe Corporation and in 1901 built the first shoe factory south of the Mason-Dixon Line. This brick warehouse served as one of their factories. It also saw service time in the Civil War as a hospital for Confederate wounded. It now serves as part of the Green Front Furniture complex.

properties.name: Fork Union Drive-In Theater
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving Rr 1, Fork Union, VAThe map is a little off. The drive-in is located one mile south of Fork Union, off U.S. Highway 15 on Route 612 (turn at the BP station). Radio sound on 90.3 FM, car speakers also available. No pets, no tables, no coolers, no large boxes, car seats or cribs outside vehicle. No glass, no laser lights, no food preparation, no grills, no candles, no cameras, no recording devices, no trailers, no tents, cell phones silent. Operate rain or shine, concession stand opens early and gate opens at 7 PM. Showtime at dusk. Call 434-842-3624 for more information (current as of 9/06). Virginia\'s smallest drive in, open seasonally since 1953, currently 3 nights a week from April to October (Fri.-Sun.). Double feature each night. adults, 6-10 years, free for 5 and under.

properties.name: Fort Stevens State Park
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving seaside, orHome to a fort that served from the Civil War to WWII. Has the distinction of being the only part of the American mainland fired on during WWII (by a Japanese sub off the coast). The remnants of the fort (concrete bunker) are open to the public to walk through and on... worth seeing!

properties.name: High Bridge :: Farmville, VA
properties.description: Posted by ShaunirvingWhen constructed, this span was the world\'s largest bridge (not the tallest, nor the longest, but the largest overall). It served as a vital strategic objective during the war and was eventually claimed by Union troops--after Confederate troops tried to burn both the span and its sister wagon bridge. Union forces were able to save the wagon bridge over which the II Corps crossed in pursuit of Lee’s army. Failure to destroy this bridge enabled Union forces to catch up with the Confederates at Farmville.

properties.name: Norfolk & Western Passenger Station :: Farmville, VA
properties.description: Posted by ShaunirvingOpened in 1903, the depot served as a vital transportation link for Farmville and the surrounding community. In 1979, it even served as the setting for a nationally-broadcast Pepsi commercial. After the cancellation of rail service in the 1990s, the town rallied to save the structure. It has since been restored and serves as an asset to the community.

properties.name: Opening Credits from the Movie Sommersby
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving While most of the film Sommersby, staring Richard Gere, Jodie Foster and James Earl Jones, was shot in other parts of the state, Farmville played host to the film for a few days of shooting. This spot is featured in the opening credits in two places: to the immediate north about 15 feet is where the scene of two lynched men hanging was shot, to the east is the warehouse cleanup scene (in which Richard Gere rides by a fire in the middle of the road).

properties.name: PQ's BBQ
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving13579 midlothian tnpk., midlothian, vaSome of Richmond\'s best dining! It\'s a hike out of town, but well worth the trip. Family restaurant in a strip shopping, the type with its ceiling covered from wall to wall with Nascar inflatables. The setting\'s far from fancy (think lawn chairs and checkered tablecloths) but the food is most excellent. Its strength is in its side dishes--excellent collards and hush puppies. Massive servings and B+ barbecue.

properties.name: Randolph House :: Prince Edward Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving On this site stood the hotel in which Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee stayed during his retreat from Grant\'s army (days before his eventual surrender at Appomattox). It is said that the last parade of Confederate soldiers took place on Main Street in front of this hotel. As Confederate forces evacuated Farmville, Union troops moved in shortly thereafter. In fact, Grant spent the night in the exact same room Lee had the evening before.

properties.name: Ray Winder Field :: Home of the Arkansas Travelers
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving401 s. monroe st., little rock, arOne of America\'s most historic and beautiful minor league stadiums. The park is home to the AA affiliate of the Anaheim Angels. 2006 will be Ray Winder\'s last year of service; the baseball team will be moving to the newly-constructed Dickey Stephens Park on the Little Rock waterfront in 2007.

properties.name: The Ballpark :: Former Home of the Maine Guides (AAA)
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving136 saco ave., old orchard beach, me6,500-seat stadium which served as the home for the AAA Maine Guides (Indians) and AAA Maine Phillies for about 6 years in the 1980s. The stadium has since sat dormant, after intermittent use as a concert venue. The Ballpark was built a few years too early, at a time when modern superparks with many amenities were just around the corner.

properties.name: The Byrd Theatre :: Richmond, VA
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving  2908 W. Cary St., Richmond, VAThe Byrd, which opened in 1928, is one of America\'s true movie palaces. Seating about 1,400 patrons (both downstairs and balcony) the theater features intricate plaster mouldings, polished marble walls, and a tremendous crystal chandelier. The theater shows mostly second-run movies for .99 (the price was just 99 cents until recent years) and occasionally hosts other events (like the annual VCU French Film Festival). On Friday and Saturday nights, theater patrons can hear Bob Gulledge play on "the mighty Wurlitzer organ"--the only one nationally played on a regualr basis, aside from the one at Radio City Music Hall in New York. Weekday patrons get to enjoy the litter PSA, shot in the 1980s at the Byrd... which could well hold the record for most-played PSA anywhere.

properties.name: The Diamond :: Home of the Richmond Braves (AAA)
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving3001 N. Boulevard, Richmond, VABuilt in 1985 on the site of historic Parker Field, the Diamond is home to the AAA affiliate of the Atlanta Braves. 2006 will be one of the last seasons the Braves call the park home; negotiations are underway for a new stadium (tentatively to be built at the former Fulton Gas Works site just east of downtown Richmond).

properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving Walker\'s Diner :: 307 N. Main St., FarmvilleManufactured by the Valentine Co. of Wichita, KS, Walker\'s Diner is believed to have been delivered to Farmville by rail in two pieces in either 1950 or 1951. The original owner was Trent Walker. The current owners are John and Anita Bolinger. Diner has 15 stools, with the addition of awnings and wooden walls. It\'s one of the few places you\'ll find eggs and brains on the menu.

properties.name: Wrigley Field Bleachers and Scoreboard
properties.description: Posted by Shaunirving1060 W. Addison st., chicago, ilThe Wrigley Field bleachers and scoreboard were constructed in 1937 when the outfield area was renovated to provide improved and expanded seating ... the original scoreboard remains intact.

properties.name: Wrigley Field Lights
properties.description: Posted by ShaunirvingWrigley Field added lights in 1988. The first night game took place August 8 against Philadelphia, but was rained out after 31/2 innings. The first official night game occurred August 9 vs. New York, when the Cubs defeated the Mets 6-4.
